fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, an object Fx\in D;
for each morphism f\in C(x, y), a morphism Ff\in D(Fx, Fy).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must preserve the structure of the category, namely identities and composites, meaning:

fr:ul.fr:li: for each object x\in C, F1_x = 1_{Fx};
for each pair x\xrightarrow {f}y\xrightarrow {g}z in C, F(gf) = (Fg)(Fg).

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} E be any functor, where E is cocomplete and locally small. Because the simplex category is small, the left Kan extension L of F along the Yoneda embedding into simplicial sets exists and is computed by the colimit formula. Moreover, this functor is left adjoint to the functor E\xrightarrow {R} sSet acting by x\mapsto n\mapsto E(Fn, x):

fr:link.title: A leisurely introduction to simplicial sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \Delta \xrightarrow {F} Cat send n in the abstract simplex to the ordinal category n. Then the nerve functor N is the right adjoint to the Kan extension of F to the category of simplicial sets. In particular, as n-simplices, FC has functors Fn\to C.

More concretely, let C be a small category. The nerve of C is the simplicial set whose n-simplicies are n-long strings of composable maps in C. The degeneracy map s_i takes a string of length n and inserts an identity at position i, while the face map d_i composes the ith and i+1st arrows (or else leaves out the first or last arrow, if i=0 or i=n.)

fr:title.text: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Projection from categories of elements creates (co)limits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In particular, the forgetful functor from an over category C/c strictly creates all connected limits that C admits and all colimits that C admits.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors and suppose that the colimit \operatorname *{colim}(K\downarrow d\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) exists for each d\in D. Then these colimits define the action on objects of the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K F} E, and furthermore the unit of the Kan extension is determined by the colimit cone.
Dually, the limits \operatorname *{lim}(d\downarrow K\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) define the right Kan extension \operatorname *{Ran}_K F.

By the universal property of right Kan extensions, the right Kan extension of F along 1_C is F itself. Since this diagram is preserved by all functors, we conclude that this extension is pointwise, in which case (noting that c\downarrow 1_C = c/C) it is computed by the limit formula Fc\cong \operatorname *{lim}(c/C\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} D). Now the result follows by the construction of limits from equalizers and products.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf for C locally small. Then F is the colimit of the diagram \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xhookrightarrow {y} \hat {C}, where y is the Yoneda embedding.

fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions along fully faithful functors are isomorphisms

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The unit of the pointwise Kan extension of a functor F along a fully faithful functor K is an isomorphism.

Let D\xrightarrow {F} C and E\xrightarrow {G} C be functors. There are two canonical projection functors F\downarrow G\xrightarrow {\Pi _D} D and F\downarrow G\xrightarrow {\Pi _E} E from the comma category which forget the rest of the structure. Moreover, there is a canonical natural transformation F\Pi _D\to G\Pi _E which, at an object d\in D, e\in E, Fd\xrightarrow {f} Gd\in C, has component f.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors. Then a left Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-free object \operatorname *{Lan}_K F on F. Dually, a right Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-cofree object \operatorname *{Ran}_K F on F.

In other words, the universal property of a left Kan extension asks for a bijection E^C(F, GK)\cong E^D(\operatorname *{Lan}_K F, G) natural in D\xrightarrow {G} E: \operatorname *{Lan}_K F represents the functor E^D\xrightarrow {K^*} E^C\xrightarrow {\operatorname {Hom}(F, -)} Set.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is conservative if it reflects isomorphisms, i.e. if for any map x\xrightarrow {f} y in C, if F(f) is an isomorphism, then so is f.
A functor is finitary if it preserves filtered colimits.

Let D\xrightarrow {U} C be a functor and c\in C an object. Then a U-free object on c represents the functor C(c, U-). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(c, Uz)\cong D(d, z) natural in z\in D. In other words, it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a left adjoint F to U.

Dually, a U-cofree object on c represents the functor C(U-, c). Explicitly, it is an object d\in D equipped with a bijection C(Uz, c)\cong D(z, d) natural in z\in D: it satisfies the universal property that Fc would have, for a right adjoint F to U.

Let C\xrightarrow {K} D be a functor and E a category. Suppose that, for each C\xrightarrow {F} E, the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} F exists. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor E^C \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K} E^D that is left adjoint to the precomposition functor E^D \xrightarrow {K^*} E^C.
Dually, if the right Kan extensions \operatorname *{Ran}_K F all exist, this extends into a right adjoint to K^*.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: By definition, Kan extensions are (co)free, and (co)free assignments extend uniquely to adjunctions.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A subcategory of a category C is a collection of objects and morphisms from C closed under composition and containing all the identities. Following the pattern of subobjects, we identify a subcategory with the inclusion [functor] into C; in this sense, a subcategory is a faithful and injective on objects functor.
A limit is absolute if it is preserved by all functors.
Since functors preserve equations and the property of being a split coequalizer is equationally witnessed, it is preserved by any functor.

To show the universal property of the coequalizer, let y\xrightarrow {k}w be such that kf = kg. By the equality ksh = kft = kgt = k, is this a factorization, as desired. Uniqueness follows because h is a retract, hence in particular an epi.

An adjunction is monadic if the comparison functor to the Eilenberg-Moore category is an equivalence of categories. A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is monadic if it is the left adjoint in a monadic adjunction; in this case D is monadic over C.
An adjunction F \dashv G between categories C and D entails the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a pair of functors F:C\leftrightarrows D:G, called the left and right adjoints;
a family of natural bijections D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition;
a natural transformation 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF, called the unit;
a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D, called the counit.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data relates as follows:

fr:ul.fr:li: the component c\xrightarrow {\eta _c}GFc of the unit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Fc};
the component FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d}d of the counit is the transpose of the identity 1_{Gd};
the transposition of a map Fc\xrightarrow {f} d is the composite c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} GFc\xrightarrow {Gf} Gd;
the transposition of a map c\xrightarrow {g} Gd is the composite Fc\xrightarrow {Fg} FGd\xrightarrow {\epsilon _d} d;

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:title.text: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Adjoints are unique up to unique isomorphism

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F and F' be left adjoints to G. Then there is a unique natural isomorphism \theta : F\cong F' commuting with the units and counits of the adjunctions.
Dually, right adjoints are also unique up to unique isomorphism commuting with the units and counits.
To show uniqueness, note that \theta _c is uniquely specified as the transpose of \eta '_c across the adjunction F\dashv G, but this relationship is required for commutativity with the units to hold.
There are composite bijections of hom-sets E(F'Fc, e)\cong D(Fc, G'E)\cong C(c, GG'e).

Let \eta and \epsilon be the unit and counits of the adjunction F\dashv G. We give a unit \eta ' and counit \epsilon ' witnessing the adjunction F_*\dashv G_*. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {H} C, the component H\xrightarrow {\eta '_H} GFH is the whiskered natural transformation \eta H. Given a functor J\xrightarrow {K} D, the component FGK\xrightarrow {\epsilon '_K} K is similarly \epsilon K.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor so that, for each object d\in D, there exists a cofree object Gd\in C, i.e. an object Gd\in C together with an isomorphism {D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd)} natural in D. Then there exists a unique extension of this assignment into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C, which is then necessarily right adjoint to F.
Dually, suppose that for each d\in D, there exists a free object Fd\in C. Then this data extends uniquely into a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C which is necessarily left adjoint to F.

fr:title.text: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Properties of adjoint functors relate to those of their (co)units

fr:title.text: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints preserve limits; left adjoints preserve colimits

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Right adjoints preserve limits. Dually, left adjoints preserve colimits.

Letting \Delta be the constant diagram functor, we have the following series of natural isomorphisms: \begin {aligned} C^J(\Delta c, GK) &\cong D^J(F\Delta c, K) &&\text {by (1)}\\\\ &\cong D^J(\Delta Fc, K) &&\text {by (2)}\\\\ &\cong D(Fc, \operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the definition of limits}\\\\ &\cong C(c, G\operatorname *{lim}_J K) &&\text {by the adjunction}. \end {aligned} By definition of limits, this exhibits G\operatorname *{lim}_J K as a limit of GK.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with locally small complete domain D. Suppose that D satisfies the solution set condition: for each object c in C, there exists a small family of maps c\xrightarrow {f_i} Gd_i in C such that any map c\xrightarrow {f} Gd factors through one of the f_i via the G-image of a map d_i\to d in D. Then G admits a left adjoint.

Let D\xrightarrow {G} C be a continuous functor with complete domain and locally small domain and codomain. Suppose that D has a small coseparating family and that every collection of subobjects x_\alpha \hookrightarrow x in D admits a meet, i.e. a limit. Then G has a left adjoint.
An endofunctor is an endomorphic functor, i.e. a functor whose domain and codomain agree. The endofunctor category over a category C is the functor category C^C.
A functor is called cocontinuous if it preserves colimits.
A functor is called continuous if it preserves limits.

fr:title.text: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Right adjoints are initial in a comma category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A functor D\xrightarrow {G} C is a right adjoint if and only if, for each c\in C, the comma category c\downarrow G has an initial object. Dually, C\xrightarrow {F} D is a left adjoint if and only if, for each d\in D, the comma category F\downarrow d has a terminal object. (Here, c is the constant functor at c.)
In the forwards direction, we obtain the result since adjoint assignments are universal and universal elements are initial in exactly the specified category of elements.

In the backwards direction, let c\xrightarrow {\eta _c} Gd_0 be initial in c\downarrow G; let Fc = d_0. Initiality of \eta _c means that, for any map c\to Gd, there is a unique map Fc\to d in D making the triangle commute. In other words, \eta _c determines a bijection C(c, Gd)\cong D(Fc, d). Moreover, this bijection is natural in D, since it comes from the natural isomorphism which defines the colimit \eta _c. Thus, this data extends to an adjunction.

fr:title.text: The constant diagram functor commutes with functors

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The constant diagram functor commutes with functors

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The constant diagram functor \Delta commutes with other functors. In particular, for any category J and functor C\xrightarrow {F} D, C\xrightarrow {\Delta } C^J\xrightarrow {F_*} D^J= C\xrightarrow {F} D\xrightarrow {\Delta } D^J.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: On the left, we have the action c\mapsto (j\mapsto c)\mapsto (j\mapsto c\mapsto Fc); on the right, we have the action c\mapsto Fc\mapsto (j\mapsto Fc). These agree.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F: C\leftrightarrows D: G be a pair of opposing functors. Then the following are equivalent specifications of an adjunction:

fr:ul.fr:li: there exists a natural bijection D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd);
there exists a pair of natural transformations 1_C\xrightarrow {\eta } GF and FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D satisfying the triangle identities;

there exists a natural transformation FG\xrightarrow {\epsilon } 1_D so that the formula for adjoint maps induces an isomorphism (-)^\sharp = C(c, Gd)\xrightarrow {F} D(Fc, FGd)\xrightarrow {(\epsilon _d)_*} D(Fc, d).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The first implies the second via the triangle identities of the unit and counit.

fr:title.text: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A square commutes iff its adjoint does

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In the forwards direction, suppose that the isomorphisms are natural, and further that the left-hand square commutes; the case in which the right-hand square commutes is similar. By the naturality of the isomorphism in C, the transpose of kf^\sharp is (Gk) f^\flat , while by naturality in D, the transpose of (Fh)g^\sharp is hg^\flat . Since the maps are equal, their transposes must also be equal; this is commutativity of the square on the right.

fr:ul.fr:li: H\eta = \eta 'H, where \eta and \eta ' are the units of the adjunctions;
K\epsilon = \epsilon 'K, where \epsilon and \epsilon ' are the counits of the adjunctions;
transposition commutes with H and K.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: An adjunction F\dashv G consists of a pair of opposing functors F: C\leftrightarrows D: G and a natural isomorphism D(Fc, d)\cong C(c, Gd), called transposition. We say F is left adjoint to G and G is right adjoint to F, and write

When an adjunction is fixed, two maps f\in C and g\in D are adjoint or transposes if they are connected by the adjunction. We sometimes write Fc\xrightarrow {f^\sharp } d and c\xrightarrow {f^\flat } Gd for a pair of adjoint maps.
Let J be an index category and let C be J-complete. Then there is a functor C^J \xrightarrow {\operatorname *{lim}_J} C which acts on functors by taking the limit.
Note that this theorem relies on a choice of witnesses to the completeness of C, i.e. a canonical choice of limit of each J-shaped diagram.
Cat is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the product category. The equalizer of functors C\overset {F,G}{\rightrightarrows } D is the subcategory of C consisting of objects x such that Fx = Gx and morphisms f such that Ff = Gf.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D creates limits if it reflects limits and, for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C, if FK has a limit in D, then there is a limit cone of K in C whose image under F is a limit cone of FK in D.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D preserves limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every limit cone over K, the image of this cone under F is a limit cone over FK.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D reflects limits if for every diagram J\xrightarrow {K} C and every cone over K whose image under F is a limit cone for FK, the original cone is a limit cone over K.

Let c be an object in a category C, and let J be any category. The constant functor at c is the functor J\xrightarrow {c} C that sends every object of J to c and every morphism of J to the identity 1_c.

The constant functors induce a functor C\xrightarrow {\Delta } J^C to the functor category which sends each object of C to the corresponding constant functor and each morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y to the natural transformation with components \alpha _j = f for each j\in J.
A commutatitive diagram in a category C is a functor J\xrightarrow {D} C. The domain J is called the indexing category or the shape of the diagram.

fr:title.text: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Universal elements are initial or terminal

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements \text {el}(F) has a initial object. Dually, a presheaf C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if and only if its category of elements has a terminal object.

First let c\in C represent F, so that there is a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F. Then the pair (c, \alpha _c(1_c)) is initial in \text {el}(F). Indeed, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), the bijection \alpha _d determines a unique element f\in C(c, d) so that Ff(\alpha _c(1_c)) = y; this exactly expresses initiality.

Conversely, let (c, x) be initial in \text {el}(F). By the Yoneda lemma, the element x\in Fc determines a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\Phi (x)} F; we need to show this is an isomorphism. Initiality of (c, x) asserts that, for any (d, y)\in \text {el}(F), there is a unique map c\xrightarrow {f_y} d such that Ff_y(x) = y. Now in the proof of the Yoneda lemma, \Phi (x) was constructed so that F(\Phi (x)_d)(f) = Ff(x), so the assignment (d, y)\mapsto f_y inverts \Phi (x)_d.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor. The category of elements \text {el}(F) is the comma category *\downarrow F, where *\xrightarrow {*} Set is the inclusion of the point into the singleton set. Explicitly, the category of elements has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, pairs (c, x) where c\in C and x\in Fc;
as morphisms (c, x)\to (d, y), morphisms c\xrightarrow {f} d in C such that Ff(x) = y;
composition and identities inherited from C.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The category of elements is further endowed with a forgetful functor \text {el}(F)\xrightarrow {\Pi } C sending (c, x) to c.
Let D\xrightarrow {F} C and E\xrightarrow {G} C be functors. Then the comma category F\downarrow G has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, triples (d\in D, e\in E, Fd\xrightarrow {f} Ge\in C);
composition by gluing along the bottom and top;
identities as in D and E.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose we are given a representation C(c, -)\overset {\alpha }{\cong } F of a functor C\xrightarrow {F} D. Then by the construction of the bijection in the Yoneda lemma, we can compute the universal element characterizing this representation as \alpha _c(1_c).
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is faithful if it induces injective maps on hom-sets.
A forgetful functor is morally a functor which "forgets" some of the structure of its domain category.
A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is full if it induces surjective maps on hom-sets.

A (covariant) functor C\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(c, -)\cong F to the covariant hom-functor. A representation of F is a choice of such data.
Dually, a contravariant functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set is representable if there exists an object c\in C and a natural isomorphism C(-, c)\cong F to the contravariant hom-functor.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and let c\in C be an object. By the Yoneda lemma, a choice of x\in Fc corresponds to a natural transformation C(c, -)\xrightarrow {\alpha _x} F. Such a choice expresses a universal property of c if \alpha _x is an isomorphism, and hence a representation. In this case, x is called a universal element.
The analogous dual definition applies to presheaves.

Let C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {F} Set be a presheaf and A\in C an object. Let y be the Yoneda embedding and \hat {C} be the presheaf category. Then \hat {C}(yA, F)\cong FA, and this bijection is natural in F and A. Furthermore, the image of a natural transformation yA\xrightarrow {\alpha } F under this bijection is \alpha _A(1_A).
Dually, let C\xrightarrow {F} Set be a functor and A\in C an object. Then \operatorname {Hom}(C(A, -), F)\cong FA.
We prove the contravariant (presheaf) case. The proof is in three parts: the bijection, and the two naturality claims.
A bifunctor is a functor whose domain is a product category.
A contravariant functor between categories C and D is a functor F: C^\text {op}\to D.

Let c be an object in a category C. The contravariant hom-functor C^\text {op}\xrightarrow {C(-, c)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(x, c) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f^* by pre-composition:
This functor is also called the presheaf represented by c, and is written yc, y^c or h^c, the former two in reference to the Yoneda embedding.

Let c be an object in a category C. The covariant hom-functor C\xrightarrow {C(c, -)} Set takes an object x to the hom-set C(c, x) and a morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y to its action f_* by post-composition:
This functor is also called the functor represented by c, and is written y_c or h_c, the first in reference to the Yoneda embedding.
The direct image functor \mathcal {P}: Set\to Set takes a set to its powerset and a map X\xrightarrow {f}Y to its action f_* by direct images, i.e. f_*(A) = \{y\in Y :\exists x\in A, f(x) = y\}.

A functor C\xrightarrow {F} D is an equivalence of categories if there exists a functor D\xrightarrow {G} C together with natural isomorphisms FG\cong 1_D and GF\cong 1_C. Two categories are equivalent if there exists an equivalence of categories between them, in which case we write C\simeq D .
Let C and D be categories. The functor category D^C has:

fr:ul.fr:li: as objects, functors C\to D;
as morphisms, natural transformations;
as composition, vertical composition;
as identities, the identity natural transformations.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Functors preserve isomorphisms.
Explicitly, let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor. If x\xrightarrow {f} y is an isomorphism in C, then Ff is an isomorphism in D.
The inverse is Ff^{-1}. We have (Ff^{-1})(Ff) = F(f^{-1}f) = F(1_x) = 1_{F(x)}, and the same works on the other side.

Let C\xrightarrow {F,F'}D and D\xrightarrow {G,G'}E be functors with F\xrightarrow {\alpha } F' and G\xrightarrow {\beta } G' natural transformations. Then their horizontal composite GF\xrightarrow {\beta *\alpha } G'F' is a natural transformation with components given by the following commutative square:
Diagramatically:

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \begin {tikzcd}[baseline=(current bounding box.center)] C\ar [rr, "F", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "F'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \alpha & D\ar [rr, "G", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta & E & \rightsquigarrow & C \ar [rr, "GF", bend left=50]\ar [rr, "G'F'"', bend right=50] & \Downarrow \beta *\alpha & E\makebox [0pt][l]{.} \\ \end {tikzcd}

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C\xrightarrow {F} D be a functor. The identity natural transformation F\xrightarrow {1_F} F is the natural transformation with components (1_F)_c = 1_{Fc}.
Let C be a category. The identity functor C\xrightarrow {1_C}C sends each object and morphism to itself.

A natural transformation F\xrightarrow {\alpha } G between functors C\xrightarrow {F,G} D consists of, for every object x\in C, a morphism \alpha _x: Fx\to Gx (the components) such that, for every morphism x\xrightarrow {f}y in C, the following diagram commutes:
A category C consists of the following data:

fr:ul.fr:li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y\in C, a collection of morphisms C(x, y);
for each object x\in C, a designated identity morphism x\xrightarrow {1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g} z, a designated composite morphism x\xrightarrow {gf} z.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

fr:ul.fr:li: unitality: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x\xrightarrow {f} y\xrightarrow {g}z\xrightarrow {h}w, h(gf) = (hg)f.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
